conceptual_evolution.label: Evolution of τὸ ἐφ' ἡμῖν (to eph' hêmin)

controversy.label: Luther vs. Erasmus Debate on Free Will
controversy.description: Foundational Reformation controversy between Martin Luther and Erasmus on the bondage vs. freedom of the will. Erasmus (1524): humans possess weakened but genuine free will; Scripture ambiguous; moder

controversy.label: De Auxiliis Controversy
controversy.description: Major Catholic theological controversy between Jesuits (Molinists) and Dominicans (Bañezians) over reconciling divine grace with human freedom. Molinists defended middle knowledge and simultaneous con

controversy.label: Hobbes vs. Bramhall Debate on Liberty and Necessity
controversy.description: Extended debate between Thomas Hobbes and Bishop John Bramhall on freedom, determinism, and moral responsibility. Hobbes defended mechanistic determinism and compatibilism (liberty = absence of extern

controversy.label: Hume vs. Reid on Causation and Free Will
controversy.description: Scottish Enlightenment debate between David Hume's compatibilism and Thomas Reid's agent-causation libertarianism. Hume argued for regularity theory of causation and compatibilism. Reid rejected Hume'

controversy.label: Synod of Dort
controversy.description: International Reformed synod convened to address Arminian Remonstrant challenge to Calvinist orthodoxy. Condemned five points of Arminianism; affirmed five points of Calvinism (TULIP): Total depravity

debate.label: The Compatibility Question
debate.description: The central question in free will debates: **Is freedom compatible with determinism?** This question divides philosophers into compatibilists (freedom and determinism can coexist) and incompatibilists

debate.label: Internal vs External Causes
debate.description: The debate over whether actions originate from **internal** (character, desires, reason) or **external** (fate, environment, prior causes) sources. Related to the ancient debate between **eph' hêmin**

debate.label: Providence, Foreknowledge, and Freedom
debate.description:
The ancient theological problem: **If God foreknows all future events, are they necessary?** If so, human freedom seems impossible.

**Origins**: Discussed by Aristotle (sea battle, De Int. 9), intens

debate.label: Intellectualism vs Voluntarism
debate.description:
The medieval debate: Which faculty is **primary** in human action - **intellect** (reason) or **will**?

**Intellectualism** (Aquinas, Dominicans):
- Intellect is primary: **will necessarily follows l

debate.label: The Randomness/Luck Objection to Libertarianism
debate.description:
The objection that **libertarian free will makes choices random/lucky** rather than free. If choices are not determined by reasons/character, they seem arbitrary.

**The objection**: If agent has genu

debate.label: Stoic-Academic Debate on Fate
debate.description: Central Hellenistic debate between Stoics (esp. Chrysippus) and Academic Skeptics (esp. Carneades) on fate, determinism, and moral responsibility

debate.label: Christian-Gnostic Debate on Freedom
debate.description: Patristic debate on human freedom (autexousion) vs cosmic determinism between Christian theologians and Gnostic teachers

debate.label: Augustine-Pelagius on Grace and Free Will
debate.description: Foundational Christian debate on the relationship between divine grace and human free will

debate.label: Alexander vs Stoics on Determinism
debate.description: Alexander of Aphrodisias' Peripatetic defense of libertarian free will against Stoic compatibilism

event.label: Council of Carthage (418 CE)
event.description: Major council that condemned Pelagianism as heresy in eight (or nine) canons, fully approved Augustine's views on original sin, grace, and infant baptism. Gave 'death blow' to Pelagianism

event.label: Second Council of Orange (529 CE)
event.description: Council that condemned Semi-Pelagianism, affirmed Augustinian doctrines of corruption, human inability, prevenient grace, and baptismal regeneration, while denying strict double predestination

person.label: Jean Buridan (attributed)
person.description: Jean Buridan (c. 1300-1358 CE) was a French nominalist philosopher at the University of Paris, known for logic, physics, and the famous thought experiment "Buridan's Ass." Though never formally attrib

person.label: Pierre Bayle
person.description: Pierre Bayle (1647-1706 CE), French Huguenot philosopher and skeptic, authored the influential *Historical and Critical Dictionary*. He argued that reason cannot resolve the problem of evil, divine fo

person.label: Erasmus of Rotterdam
person.description: Dutch Renaissance humanist and Catholic theologian. Defended human free will against Luther's determinism, arguing for synergistic cooperation between divine grace and human choice. Emphasized moral r

person.label: Jacobus Arminius
person.description: Dutch Reformed theologian who challenged strict Calvinist predestination. Argued for conditional predestination based on God's foreknowledge of faith, prevenient grace enabling free choice, and resist

person.label: Franciscus Gomarus
person.description: Dutch Calvinist theologian and primary opponent of Arminius. Defended strict supralapsarian predestination and unconditional election. Leading voice at Synod of Dort against Arminian 'Remonstrants'.

person.label: Luis de Molina (expanded)
person.description: Spanish Jesuit theologian who developed the doctrine of middle knowledge (scientia media) to reconcile divine sovereignty with human free will. Argued God knows what every possible free creature would

person.label: Domingo Báñez
person.description: Spanish Dominican theologian and opponent of Molinism. Defended Thomist doctrine of physical premotion (praemotio physica): God physically predetermines all free acts while preserving their freedom. A

person.label: Cornelius Jansen (Jansenius)
person.description: Dutch Catholic theologian and Bishop of Ypres. Developed rigorous Augustinian theology emphasizing human depravity, irresistible grace, and limited atonement—anticipating aspects of Calvinism within C

person.label: Blaise Pascal
person.description: French mathematician, physicist, and theologian allied with Jansenist movement at Port-Royal. Defended Jansenism against Jesuits in Provincial Letters. Emphasized human wretchedness without grace, lim

person.label: Antoine Arnauld
person.description: French Catholic theologian, philosopher, and leading Jansenist. Collaborated with Pascal defending Jansenism. Engaged in major philosophical debates with Descartes, Malebranche, and Leibniz on ideas,

person.label: René Descartes (expanded)
person.description: French philosopher and founder of modern rationalism. Developed systematic philosophy based on methodological doubt and cogito argument. On free will: defended libertarian freedom grounded in infinite

person.label: Nicolas Malebranche
person.description: French Oratorian priest and Cartesian philosopher who developed occasionalism: God is the only true cause; finite beings are merely occasions for divine action. On free will: defended libertarian free

person.label: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
person.description: German polymath and rationalist philosopher. Developed compatibilist theory reconciling determinism with freedom through distinction between necessity and contingency, and between moral necessity and

person.label: Christian Wolff
person.description: German philosopher who systematized and popularized Leibnizian philosophy. Developed compatibilist position based on Principle of Sufficient Reason. Defended determinism while arguing for moral respon

person.label: Thomas Hobbes
person.description: English philosopher who developed mechanistic materialism and compatibilist theory of freedom. Defined liberty as absence of external impediments; denied liberty of indifference. Freedom compatible wi

person.label: John Bramhall
person.description: Anglican Bishop of Derry and defender of libertarian free will against Hobbes's determinism. Argued that Hobbesian necessity destroys moral responsibility, deliberation, and divine justice. Defended l

person.label: John Locke
person.description: English empiricist philosopher. Developed influential analysis of freedom, power, and moral responsibility. Distinguished freedom of action from liberty of will. Argued the will is not free (category

person.label: Anthony Collins
person.description: English deist and determinist who argued for universal necessity and denied libertarian free will. Maintained determinism supports morality by making behavior predictable and improvable through educat

person.label: Samuel Clarke
person.description: English philosopher and Anglican clergyman. Defended libertarian free will as necessary for moral responsibility and divine justice. Argued against Leibnizian sufficient reason and Hobbesian necessity

person.label: David Hume
person.description: Scottish empiricist and skeptical philosopher. Developed influential compatibilist position: liberty = acting according to will; necessity = regular conjunction. Argued liberty and necessity are compa

person.label: Thomas Reid
person.description: Scottish philosopher and founder of Common Sense school. Developed agent-causation theory of free will in explicit opposition to Hume's compatibilism. Argued persons as agents cause their actions with

person.label: Immanuel Kant
person.description: German Enlightenment philosopher who revolutionized Western philosophy. Developed transcendental idealism distinguishing phenomena from noumena. On free will: argued Third Antinomy shows theoretical r

person.label: Susanne Bobzien
person.description: Leading scholar on ancient free will debates and their modern reception. Author of "Determinism and Freedom in Stoic Philosophy" (1998) and "The Inadvertent Conception and Late Birth of the Free Will

person.label: Michael Frede
person.description: Influential historian of ancient philosophy who traced the origins of free will concept. Author of "A Free Will: Origins of the Notion in Ancient Thought" (2011). Argued that the notion of free will f

person.label: Richard Sorabji
person.description: Scholar of ancient philosophy and its reception. Director of the Ancient Commentators Project. Author of "Emotion and Peace of Mind" (2000) on Stoic emotion theory and its modern relevance.

person.label: Ricardo Salles
person.description: Scholar of Stoic philosophy and its modern parallels. Author of "The Stoics on Determinism and Compatibilism" (2008), comparing ancient Stoic arguments with contemporary analytical philosophy.

person.label: Brad Inwood
person.description: Leading Stoic scholar examining ancient ethics in contemporary philosophy. Editor and translator of major Stoic texts. Studies how Stoic concepts inform modern moral philosophy.

person.label: Martha Nussbaum
person.description: Philosopher connecting ancient Stoic and Aristotelian ethics to contemporary issues. Author of "The Therapy of Desire" examining Hellenistic philosophy's relevance to modern ethics.

person.label: Julia Annas
person.description: Scholar reviving ancient virtue ethics in contemporary philosophy. Author of "The Morality of Happiness" showing how ancient eudaimonism relates to modern ethics.

person.label: László Bernáth
person.description: Scholar comparing Stoic and Frankfurtian approaches to free will. Author of "Stoicism and Frankfurtian Compatibilism" (2018), identifying crucial differences despite surface similarities.

work.label: A Free Will: Origins of the Notion in Ancient Thought
work.description: Traces the emergence of free will concept from Epictetus through Augustine. Argues free will is a late ancient innovation, not present in classical Greek philosophy.

work.label: Determinism and Freedom in Stoic Philosophy
work.description: Comprehensive analysis of Stoic compatibilism and its influence on modern debates. Links Chrysippus to contemporary compatibilist theories.

work.label: The Stoics on Determinism and Compatibilism
work.description: Examines Stoic arguments in light of contemporary analytical philosophy, showing parallels and differences.

work.label: Emotion and Peace of Mind
work.description: Studies Stoic emotion theory and its reception in modern philosophy of mind and cognitive therapy.

work.label: Stoicism and Frankfurtian Compatibilism
work.description: Compares Stoic and Frankfurt's hierarchical theories, finding important differences despite surface similarities.
